conclusion: Looking at the image, I can see four objects on a textured surface (likely a ceiling or wall) with their shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
Object A appears to be a small circular cookie or pastry with pink/red topping.
Object B is a small yellow notepad or calendar.
Object C's object isn't clearly visible but has a shadow.
The shadows (A, B, C, D) are currently cast on the surface behind the objects.
When a light source illuminates an object, the shadow forms on the opposite side from the light source.
The shadow's size depends on the distance between the object and the surface, and the distance between the light source and the object.

premise: When the light source moves forward (closer to the objects), all shadows will move backward (away from the objects).
conclusion: The shadows will move further from their respective objects.

premise: When the light source moves closer, all shadows will become larger/longer.
conclusion: This happens because as the light source gets closer, the angle of light rays passing around the object becomes wider, creating a larger shadow.

premise: For shadow A (cookie/pastry), position will move backward, further from the cookie.
For shadow B (yellow notepad), position will move backward, further from the notepad.
For shadow C (unknown object), position will move backward, further from its object.

When the light source moves forward (closer to the objects), shadows A, B, C, and D will all move backward (away from their respective objects).
